Maria Antonieta Peixoto Gimenes Couto

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/6932332009485079
  • Última atualização do currículo em 27/08/2019

Possui graduação em Engenharia Química pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (1984), mestrado em Tecnologia de Processos Bioquímicos pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (1990) e doutorado em Tecnologia de Processos Químicos e Bioquímicos pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (2002). Atualmente é Professora Titular do Departamento de Engenharia Bioquímica da Escola de Química da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro. Atua nos cursos de graduação em Engenharia de Bioprocessos, Engenharia Química, Engenharia de Alimentos e Química Industrial nas áreas de tecnologia de fermentações e engenharia bioquímica. Atuou como coordenadora do curso de graduação em Engenharia de Bioprocessos de 2010 a 2013. Foi membro do Conselho de Ensino de Graduação da UFRJ de 2007 a 2013 e, atualmente, é assessora da Pró-reitoria de Ensino de Graduação da UFRJ . Integra o corpo docente permanente do Mestrado Profissional em Engenharia de Biocombustíveis e Petroquímica e do Programa de Engenharia Ambiental (PEA) da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro. Em pesquisa e pós-graduação desenvolve e orienta trabalhos relacionados ao aproveitamento de biomassas residuais da produção de biocombustíveis e de alimentos com base no conceito de biorrefinarias e produção integrada. É membro do Corpo Docente do Programa de Engenharia Ambiental na Indústria de Petróleo, Gás e Biocombustíveis (PRH-41 - ANP) e da Escola Brasileira de Química Verde. Mediante parcerias com o grupo de Gestão e Inovação Tecnológica da Escola de Química/UFRJ tem realizados trabalhos voltados para a gestão em Biotecnologia. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Produção de Biofármacos por Microalgas
Descrição: O projeto visa à obtenção de biofármacos a partir do cultivo de microalgas, envolvendo estudos em escala de bancada e, ainda, a extrapolação de escala para unidade piloto..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (2) / Mestrado acadêmico: (1) .

Integrantes: Maria Antonieta Peixoto Gimenes Couto - Coordenador / Elcio Ribeiro Borges - Integrante / Anita Ferreira do Valle - Integrante / Monica Ferreira Moreira - Integrante / Michele Caldeira Magdalena Ribeiro - Integrante.
2013 - 2013
Technological Roadmap: Increase Ethanol Yield and Waste Reduction
Descrição: The necessity to reduce the dependence of the oil usage encouraged studies towards the development of new alternatives in the fuel production field. In this sense, bioethanol became an efficient option, since it is a renewable source of vegetable products. Any raw material containing carbohydrates can be converted to ethanol, provided that it undergoes a suitable treatment. In Brazil, sugarcane is the main raw material for industrial bioethanol production. In our country, bioethanol may be produced either in autonomous distilleries, on which all sugarcane is diverted for ethanol production, or in annexed plants, on which a fraction of the sugarcane is used for sugar production, and the remaining fraction along with sugarcane molasses (solution containing sugars and other impurities obtained after sucrose crystallization) are diverted for ethanol production. The energy (steam and electricity) required for the process is produced using sugarcane bagasse as fuel in cogeneration systems; if sugarcane trash is retrieved of the field, it may also be used as fuel, producing steam and electricity to meet plant s demand. The industrial production of ethanol leads to the generation of various residues from the harvest to the product purification. However, the focus of this work is the vinasse, which is the residue from the distillation of ethanol. For each liter of alcohol, it is generated, approximately, 13 liters of vinasse. Considering a projection of 25 billion liters of ethanol, the generation of vinasse will reach the amount of 312 BILLION liters, in the current year. Due to its characteristics, mainly related to its high Biochemical Oxygen Demand values (BOD = 30,000 40,000 mg/L), pH (3,5 4,9) and high concentration of mineral salts, especially Ca2+ - 600 ppm; K+ - 2000ppm; Mg2+ - 300 ppm, this residue has a high pollutant potential.The present work is focused on the study of biogas upgrading and cleanup technologies, aiming to identify the technologies for the increase of sugarcane ethanol yield associated to the reduction of vinasse production for the next 20 years, supporting General Electric (GE) on the decision-making for its investments. To achieve these goals, technical documents were analyzed, i.e., scientific articles and patents, along with companies profile and articles from specialized media. The research was organized in 3 specific phases: The first one, the Pre Technological Forecast Phase is the phase which is performed the preliminary research. It s a random search, looking for any information about the subject and aiming to base the methodology for the next step. The second one is the Technological Forecast Phase , which is based on a defined methodology with specifics keywords, searching for technical documents (scientific articles and patents) and followed by a huge analysis, sorting the documents by many criteria, such as publication year, origin country, type of author and focus (on the subject). And finally, the last step is the Post Technological Forecast Phase , where all analyses originated in the previous steps are classified according to the temporal evolution of the observed trends..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) .

Integrantes: Maria Antonieta Peixoto Gimenes Couto - Integrante / SUZANA BORSCHIVER - Coordenador.
2013 - 2013
Technological Roadmap: Sugarcane Bagasse to value Succinic Acid
Descrição: Descrição: Around the world significant steps are being taken in order to move from today s fossil based economy to a more sustainable economy based on biomass. The transition towards a bio-based economy has multiple drivers: The need to develop an environmentally, economically and socially sustainable global economy; The anticipation that oil, gas, coal and phosphorus will reach peak production in a not too distant future and that prices will climb; The desire of many countries to reduce an over dependency on fossil fuel imports, and thus the need to diversify their energy sources; The global issue of climate change and the need to reduce atmospheric greenhouse gases (GHG) emissions; And the need to stimulate regional and rural development1. In this context, lignocellulosic materials, especially agroindustry residues, have been the subject of intense research since they are renewable sources of carbon and energy and are available in large quantities2. Due to advancement in the agricultural industries, millions of tons of wastes and byproducts are generated every year that have potential as low-cost sources of energy and material. One of these byproducts is sugarcane bagasse, which can be used in the production of industrial enzymes, ethanol, xylitol, organic acids, etc. Bagasse is a residue obtained from sugarcane after it is crushed to obtain the juice used for sugar and ethanol production.Sugarcane bagasse is the main Brazilian agroindustrial residue, being produced at approximately 250 kg per ton of sugarcane. In spite of the great potential of this residual biomass of lignocellulosic composition (60-70% carbohydrates) for the production of fuels and chemicals, the majority of it is burned in sugar mills and alcohol distilleries for energy generation, and a smaller fraction is used for animal feeding; however there is still some surplus. Additionally, with the increase in cane production in response to the growth of global ethanol demand (from 66 to 125 million m3 between 2008 and 2020), more bagasse will be available.Succinic acid is traditionally manufactured from petrochemicals through expensive processes4. The conventional route to succinic acid is via the hydration of succinic anhydride which is made on purpose from hydrogenation of maleic anhydride in the liquid phase (maleic anhydride itself is obtained from benzene or butane). The reaction takes place in the presence of a heterogeneous catalyst (such as nickel or palladium complexes deposited on an inert carrier such as carbon).The present work is focused on the study of sugarcane bagasse to value succinic acid, aiming to identify technological and market trends for the next 20 years, supporting General Electric (GE) on the decision-making for its investments. To achieve these goals, technical documents were analyzed, i.e., scientific articles and patents, along with companies profile and articles from specialized media.The research was organized in 3 specific phases:The first one, the Pre Technological Forecast Phase is the phase which is performed the preliminary research. It s a random search, looking for any information about the subject and aiming to base the methodology for the next step. The second one is the Technological Forecast Phase , which is based on a defined methodology with specifics keywords, searching for technical documents (scientific articles and patents) and followed by a huge analysis, sorting the documents by many criteria, such as publication year, origin country, type of author and focus (on the subject). And finally, the last step is the Post Technological Forecast Phase , where all analyses originated in the previous steps are classified according to the temporal evolution of the observed trends. All these steps will be detailed in each specific chapter..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) .

Integrantes: Maria Antonieta Peixoto Gimenes Couto - Integrante / SUZANA BORSCHIVER - Coordenador / Karoline da Mota Coelho - Integrante.
2013 - 2013
Technological Roadmap:METHANOL FROM SUGARCANE BAGASSE AND EUCALYPTUS
Descrição: Among the various products that can be obtained from sugarcane bagasse and eucalyptus, methanol stands out as one of great potential. Methanol is one of the most important and versatile platform chemicals for chemical industry. It is mainly used to produce other chemicals, such as additives for gasoline, solvents and anti-freezes, or in the biodiesel production process. Current research efforts focus particularly on how to use methanol to produce transportation fuels (e.g. after conversion to dimethyl ether) and plastics. The current global methanol production is about 45 million tons per year and is mostly based on fossil fuels, mainly natural gas. However, methanol can also be produced from other carbon-containing feedstock, including biogas, biomass, waste streams and CO2. Bio-methanol (also called renewable methanol) is chemically identical to conventional methanol. The main advantage of bio-methanol is the reduction of fossil fuel use and greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional methanol production and the possibility to convert (by gasiﬁcation) a range of renewable feedstock into bio-methanol. The present work was focused on the study of bio-methanol, using sugarcane bagasse and eucalyptus as feedstock, aiming to identify the technologies for its production for the next 20 years, supporting General Electric (GE) on the decision-making for its investments..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Maria Antonieta Peixoto Gimenes Couto - Integrante / SUZANA BORSCHIVER - Coordenador.
